answers.text:
Hi Pam,
In turning to the Knowledge Network to look for sources, I found a bunch of great articles and documents that discuss methods for dealing with vagrancy.
Santa Monica, CA recently achieved an 8% reduction in homeless numbers through a couple of major initiatives. You can read the article about their successes here (http://icma.org/en/Article/11771/Santa_Monica_CA__Citys_Homelessness_Initiative_Leads_to_an_8_Reduction).
I also saw a question that was answered last year, but may lead you to resources that will help with your information gathering. You can see it here (http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/21656).
Homeless Solutions responded to an RFP from Dayton, OH with a proposal for ending vagrancy in the city over ten years.  See their plan here (http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/21656).
The City of Norfolk, VA was able to end homelessness for some by establishing a permanent supportive housing unit in the city. You can read an article about their success here (http://icma.org/en/Article/10040/Norfolk_VA_Strives_to_End_Homelessness).
You may have luck looking for more information on dealing with vagrancy if you search the Knowledge Network for articles and documents that have the Public Health, Public Safety, and Housing topic tags.
I hope this helps.
Best,
James Davidson
Knowledge Network Intern

author: Pamela Muse
text:
An Alliance member is looking for solutions, remedies, policies regarding “problem with a high volume of vagrants including public intoxication, sleeping/passed out on sidewalks in the downtown area, panhandling/begging and they are aggressive and intimidating when they contact citizens”
Your successful solutions, ideas or resolutions to vagrant problems is appreciated!
Pam
